articles.headline: Caterpillar to Cut Up to 10,000 Jobs, Citing Falling Demand
articles.snippet: The announcement from Caterpillar, which has been a symbol of American exporting might, helped drive down major stock indexes.
articles.abstract: The announcement from Caterpillar, which has been a symbol of American exporting might, helped drive down major stock indexes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shock waves from the volatility rocking China and emerging markets worldwide rolled through the American heartland on Thursday as Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., announced plans to cut as many as 10,000 workers, reflecting slumping demand.

articles.headline: Problems at Volkswagen Start in the Boardroom
articles.snippet: An insular governing structure, overseen by family members and labor, allowed the current scandal over the flouting of emissions standards to happen.
articles.abstract: An insular governing structure, overseen by family members and labor, allowed the current scandal over the flouting of emissions standards to happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a long tradition of scandal and skulduggery in the auto industry, but few schemes appear as premeditated as Volkswagen’s brazen move to use sophisticated software to circumvent United States emissions standards.

articles.headline: Janet Yellen Says Fed Is Likely to Raise Interest Rates This Year
articles.snippet: A week after the Fed declined to raise interest rates, the chairwoman reiterated that the central bank was not planning to wait much longer.
articles.abstract: A week after the Fed declined to raise interest rates, the chairwoman reiterated that the central bank was not planning to wait much longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve still intends to raise its benchmark interest rate this year, barring unpleasant surprises, the Fed chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said on Thursday.

articles.headline: Investors Are Mining for Water, the Next Hot Commodity
articles.snippet: Private companies like Cadiz Inc. and Poseidon Water hope to turn a profit by slaking the mounting thirst of California and the West. But the obstacles are formidable.
articles.abstract: Private companies like Cadiz Inc. and Poseidon Water hope to turn a profit by slaking the mounting thirst of California and the West. But the obstacles are formidable.
articles.lead_paragraph: CADIZ, Calif. — Gazing out of a turboprop high above his company’s main asset — 34,000 acres in the Mojave Desert with billions of gallons of fresh water locked deep below the sagebrush-dotted land — Scott Slater paints a lush picture that has enticed a hardy band of investors for a quarter-century.

articles.headline: Police Program Aims to Pinpoint Those Most Likely to Commit Crimes
articles.snippet: As Kansas City, Mo., and other cities turn to “predictive policing” to prevent violent offenses, civil rights advocates worry about profiling abuses.
articles.abstract: As Kansas City, Mo., and other cities turn to “predictive policing” to prevent violent offenses, civil rights advocates worry about profiling abuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At the request of his probation officer, Tyrone C. Brown came to a community auditorium here in June and sat alongside about 30 other mostly young black men with criminal records — men who were being watched closely by the police, just as he was.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: In Lunch for the Homeless, a Sacred Mission for Pope Francis
articles.snippet: Francis is using his celebrity to compel the cameras to show Americans a picture some might rather ignore: In Washington, he met the homeless.
articles.abstract: Francis is using his celebrity to compel the cameras to show Americans a picture some might rather ignore: In Washington, he met the homeless.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The residents of the Harriet Tubman Women’s Shelter rose at 3 a.m. on Thursday to give everyone time to shower, fix their hair and get dressed in the best clothes they had after years on and off the streets, coping with evictions, abuse and jobs that disappeared.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Email Inquiry Weighs if Aides Erred at ‘Send’
articles.snippet: An investigation raises complex questions about whether State Department officials broke laws or rules by sending information to Mrs. Clinton’s personal email account.
articles.abstract: An investigation raises complex questions about whether State Department officials broke laws or rules by sending information to Mrs. Clinton’s personal email account.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The email described a deteriorating situation in Libya, with snipers shooting people in the streets as rebels tried to unseat President Muammar el-Qaddafi and worried American diplomats in the midst of a “phased checkout” from Benghazi. It arrived in the private email account of Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, one Sunday morning in April 2011, with unforeseen consequences.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: S.E.C. Turns Its Eye to Hidden Fees in Mutual Funds
articles.snippet: First Eagle Investment Management reached an agreement with the S.E.C., and it might just be the start of the commission’s crackdown on fund companies’ hidden fees.
articles.abstract: First Eagle Investment Management reached an agreement with the S.E.C., and it might just be the start of the commission’s crackdown on fund companies’ hidden fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: As regulators have ramped up their scrutiny of private equity practices in recent years, investors have learned a lot about hidden — and dubious — fees they are paying.

articles.headline: John Boehner, House Speaker, Will Resign From Congress
articles.snippet: The move reduced the chance of a government shutdown, because Mr. Boehner is now free to push for a short-term funding measure.
articles.abstract: The move reduced the chance of a government shutdown, because Mr. Boehner is now free to push for a short-term funding measure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio barkeeper’s son who rode a conservative wave to one of the highest positions in government, said Friday he would relinquish his gavel and resign from Congress, undone by the very Republicans who swept him into power.

articles.headline: How Volkswagen Could Compensate Diesel Owners
articles.snippet: The carmaker isn’t yet saying, but potential recompense for drivers whose cars were subject to deceptive emissions tests range from minimal to generous.
articles.abstract: The carmaker isn’t yet saying, but potential recompense for drivers whose cars were subject to deceptive emissions tests range from minimal to generous.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Winterkorn, in his statement announcing his resignation as chief executive of Volkswagen this week, said he was “shocked” and “stunned” that the company had programmed some of its cars to cheat on emissions tests.
